skill.name: distributed-tracing
skill.description: Implement distributed tracing with Jaeger and Tempo to track requests across microservices and identify performance bottlenecks. Use when debugging microservices, analyzing request flows, or implementing observability for distributed systems.
skill.summary: Implement distributed tracing with Jaeger and Tempo to track requests across microservices and ident...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: The skill is documentation-only and contains no executable code or tool calls. No data access, exfiltration, or persistence patterns are present.

content.value_statement: You need visibility into request paths and latency across services. This skill guides Jaeger, Tempo, and OpenTelemetry setup and instrumentation.
actual_capabilities: Explain trace, span, and context concepts with a request flow diagram
Provide Jaeger deployment steps for Kubernetes
Provide a Jaeger Docker Compose stack with key ports
Show OpenTelemetry instrumentation examples in Python, Node.js, and Go
Describe trace context propagation headers and sampling strategies
limitations: Does not run commands or deploy infrastructure
Focuses on Jaeger and Tempo rather than other vendors
Does not generate full application codebases
Does not validate telemetry data or performance impact

use_cases.title: Tracing rollout plan
use_cases.description: Plan Jaeger or Tempo setup and sampling for a Kubernetes cluster.

use_cases.title: Service instrumentation
use_cases.description: Add OpenTelemetry tracing to Python, Node.js, or Go services.

use_cases.title: Latency investigation
use_cases.description: Analyze trace paths to find slow spans and error propagation.

prompt_templates.title: Tracing basics
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain trace, span, and context with a simple microservices example.

prompt_templates.title: Jaeger quick start
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a Docker Compose setup for Jaeger and list the important ports.

prompt_templates.title: Instrument Flask
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to instrument a Flask service with OpenTelemetry and export to Jaeger.

prompt_templates.title: Sampling strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: Recommend a production sampling strategy and explain the tradeoffs.

output_examples.input: How do I troubleshoot missing traces in Jaeger?
output: Confirm the collector endpoint and ports are reachable
Verify exporter configuration in the application
Check that sampling rate is not zero
Review application logs for exporter errors

best_practices: Use consistent span naming and service identifiers
Propagate trace context across every service boundary
Tune sampling rates to balance cost and visibility
anti_patterns: Sampling all requests in production without cost review
Using inconsistent service names across services

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. The guidance is vendor neutral and works in all three platforms.

faq.question: What are the limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It is documentation only and does not run commands or deploy tools.

faq.question: Can it integrate with my existing observability stack?
faq.answer: Yes. The OpenTelemetry concepts can be adapted to most stacks.

faq.question: Does it access or send my data?
faq.answer: No. The content contains no data access or network actions.

faq.question: What if traces do not appear?
faq.answer: Check endpoints, network connectivity, sampling settings, and application logs.

faq.question: How does it compare to vendor APM guides?
faq.answer: It is a concise open source focused guide without vendor specific tooling.
